Award.AwardTitle: EarthCube Domain End-User Workshop: Community-Based Cyberinfrastructure for Petrology and Geochemistry
Award.AbstractNarration: This workshop will bring together scientists from the petrology and geochemistry domains, data managers, sample curators, and cyberinfrastructure specialists to gather requirements and develop a vision for an advanced information and knowledge management system that will transform the way petrological and geochemical data and samples are acquired, analyzed, published, and re-used across the geosciences in the conduct of science. The outcomes of this workshop will provide guidance to the EarthCube initiative from the petrology-geochemistry community to design and develop the architecture of an Earth Science cyberinfrastructure that is aligned with the end-users' needs for data and sample access, software tools for data and metadata acquisition, workflow support, data analysis, data visualization, and modeling, computing capabilities, interoperability with data from other domains, as well as policies and procedures that address the scientists' concerns regarding, for example, data sharing, data citation, intellectual property, sample curation, and career advancement. The workshop report will be made widely accessible on the web.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funds of this award supported a workshop that was part of a series of so-called ‘EarthCube Domain End-user workshops’, which were intended to engage scientists in NSF’s effort to advance the development and use of information technology and data infrastructure to empower Earth Science research. The workshop was held at the National Museum of Natural History in Washington, DC. It brought together more than 70 scientists from the science fields of petrology, geochemistry, and volcanology (VGP) as well as curators of sample collections, data managers of relevant data and sample repositories, cyberinfrastructure experts, and other scientists engaged in EarthCube to discuss, define, and document the needs for cyberinfrastructure and related sample infrastructure in this community.

Workshop participants identified important scientific drivers for advancing cyberinfrastructure in VGP, for example, a better understanding of the co-evolution of the geo- and biosphere; forecasting and mitigation of natural hazards related to volcanoes and communicating their impacts on society; and the search for natural resources. They articulated the data and software impediments that currently prevent researchers from addressing these scientific challenges such as limitations in accessible data types; the diversity and extent of temporal and spatial scales of existing data sets; poor online discoverability and access of collections of physical samples and the overall sparse temporal and spatial coverage of existing samples; and an incomplete shared knowledge of existing data resources, expertise, specialized skills, toolsets, and lab capabilities. The workshop participants agreed on an initial set of desired data and software capabilities needed for pursuing key science questions. These included search engines and online catalogs that facilitate discovery of data, samples, models, and management tools; software packages for data analysis and visualization; and systems for sample registration, imagery, and links between samples that promote spatial contextualization of analysis. The workshop resulted in a list of recommendations for next steps to realize the cyberinfrastructure vision for this community.

One of these steps was to rescue valuable datasets that are at risk of being lost due to the upcoming retirement of investigators. Nearly 30 datasets were compiled with support from this grant, and published in the EarthChem Library as part of this project.
